*div1 type="summary"* *p*Austin to —----- [December 29, 1831?]. Attitude toward separation from Mexico and union with united States.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p*[December 29, 1831?]*/p* *p*It is not difficult for the immagination to determine what must be the future destiny of *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*. Should the *person_mentioned*Mexican Government*/person_mentioned* adopt a correct policy as to this *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned*, it will form *location_mentioned*one of the most powerful states of their confederation*/location_mentioned*, for under a judicious system it would not be [to] the interests of *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*to separate. But should the reverse of this, unfortunately be the ease, a speedy and total separation will naturally follow as a matter of course, and an independent government will probably be the result. The permanent and substantial interests of both *location_mentioned*Mexico */location_mentioned*and the *location_mentioned*U. S. of the North*/location_mentioned*, would be promoted in very many respects by the establishment of an*location_mentioned* independent republic in the middle ground*/location_mentioned*. Such a *location_mentioned*new nation*/location_mentioned* would remove the line of immediate contact which now exist *location_mentioned*between the two great republics*/location_mentioned*, and do away with those innumerable small incidents and vexatious causes of complaint and excitement which always will arise *location_mentioned*on the border limits of large nations */location_mentioned*remote from the *location_mentioned*seat of Govt*/location_mentioned*. Too feeble to be feared by either of its *person_mentioned*neighbors*/person_mentioned*, it would opperate as a kind of sacred and necessary barrier against the encroachments of either. *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*would form a *location_mentioned*compact nation,*/location_mentioned* and under the patronage and protection of both the *location_mentioned*U. S. */location_mentioned*and of *location_mentioned*M.*/location_mentioned* could sustain a respectable standing unless it should enfeeble itself by the system of *person_mentioned*negro */person_mentioned*slavery. By the existing constitution and laws this worst of evils is totally prohibited. Should this wise policy be abandoned and *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*become what *location_mentioned*Louisiana */location_mentioned*is the receptacle of the redundant and *location_mentioned*Jail */location_mentioned*delivered *person_mentioned*Slaves */person_mentioned*of other *location_mentioned*countries*/location_mentioned*, it must from necessity have a prop to lean upon and become dependent, as a*location_mentioned* *person_mentioned*slave */person_mentioned*state*/location_mentioned* it probably could not stand alone. The annexation of such an extencive *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*to the *location_mentioned*U. S*/location_mentioned*. would be a measure of such doubtful policy, that it would no doubt be opposed by reflecting men from all the *location_mentioned*states */location_mentioned*and especially by the *location_mentioned*eastern and Atlantic */location_mentioned*ones on the ground that it would endanger the *location_mentioned*union*/location_mentioned* by too great an extension of *location_mentioned*Territory to the Southwest.*/location_mentioned**/p*
